utterances: Over by the bar, there are more theories.
Kevin Sutherland(ph) thinks Cooper never made it.
He fell out of that plane and landed on a tree somewhere and died.
And Jeremy Arionas(ph) thinks he did make it.
I think that D.B.
Cooper is sitting on the beach in Mexico, drinking and having a good time, yes.
And while no one can agree on the real identity of D.B.
Cooper, Arionas and pretty much everyone else here seems to feel Cooper was some sort of hero.
He's a hero because he made it.
Yeah, he got away with something.
But just in case didn't, Arionas says when he's out hunting for elk and deer, he's also on the lookout for bits of old parachutes and some of that missing cash.
(Soundbite of people cheering)
For NPR News, I'm Harriet Baskas.
All those immigrants being cleared off our streets are beginning to flood the streets of their home countries.
The United States has cracked down on illegal immigration, sending home about 287,000 people in the past year alone.
Their stories are spreading now to people like Ann-Maria Ortiz, who is a housekeeper in El Salvador.
(Through translator) Yes, I've thought about going to the U.S., but I hear it's more dangerous now.
You hear about immigration agents and how they're sending people back.
Some people are choosing not to go, but I'm still thinking about it because we're very poor here.
NPR's Jennifer Ludden introduced us this week to a pair of people sent back to El Salvador.
Which leads us to another question, Jennifer Ludden.
What happens when a country has thousands of stories like this?
They feel overwhelmed, Steve.
We met with the director of the Ministry of Immigration in San Salvador, and he gave us the numbers.
In 2004, about 3,500 migrants from the U.S.
were deported back to El Salvador.
This past year, it was 20,000.
So it's been doubling and doubling again.
And you get a sense that officials are really scrambling to cope, trying to figure out how to help these people integrate, but they admit they're not really there yet.
People are just kind of being left to their own.
And as the minister told us, a lot of them are thinking of coming back to the U.S.
Well, what happens to the economy of a place like El Salvador when you have in a year the equivalent of a small city, 20,000 people, coming back to a very small country?
And NPR editor Ahmad Omar.
He edits this program.
Ahmad, thanks for taking four steps down the hall to come into the studio.
Well, I don't know, you know?
The weird thing about midlife in automobiles is that it's a moving target.
First of all, midlife itself is a moving target, you know?
Demographically, people who, in their 60s consider themselves in midlife.
Yeah, they're going to push that up to 80, too, you know?
I'm all in favor of - it's like, you know, he died at 80 - oh, snatched untimely from our (unintelligible)â€¦
Right.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And also the nature or the crisis has changed, you know?

It used to be midlife crisis - it used to be a calamity of machismo but now, you know, especially with regard to cars, it's about redefining yourself in midstream so that, you know, you want to be hip, you want to be cool, you want to be current, and so, with regard to cars.
Twenty years ago, you would have bought, for example, the new Corvette ZR1, which has 620 horsepower and a 200-mile per hour car.
The first $100,000 Corvette was on display at Detroit.
But you're just as likely or perhaps far more likely to buy a hybrid, to demonstrate your green credentials.
Right.
So, wait, let me ask you - I mean, of course, you're in L.A., which is, you know, a place where midlife or not, people have to have the hottest car, right, first of all?
Are you suggesting or (unintelligible)?
(Soundbite of laughter)
I just know that, you know, cars are kind of important in L.A.
(unintelligible)
And, the other thing I wonder is, is this something that's mostly a male thing that the midlife car is more important to men than to women?
Well, again, another interesting sort of tracking phenomenon with cars is that it used to be a solely male phenomenon, but now it's clearly a sexually dimorphic phenomenon.
Women have midlife crisis, and so if you're a woman, say, you know, a working woman, 50 years old, kids are growing up and you have the opportunity to sort of indulge yourself in a automobile.
Well, what would you get?
Well, you could get a new BMW 1 Series, which is the car they're coming out with.
It's a small compact convertible.
They make it in a convertible form.
And it's a very expressive and fine.
I mean, it's a reward for a life well spent.
Or, you might buy the smart car, which is this - the tiny little European city car that they're just now bringing to the United States.
I got an e-mail from a woman today who said she'd ordered the first one, and it was arriving in California, and she couldn't sleep.
She was so excited.
And I think that's clearly a manifestation of a kind of a midlife desire.
Yeah.
And am I crazy or did I see a story about a car that drives itself?
Well, yes, that's a - well, what's happening is that the good folks at the Pentagon, through DARPA, their advanced research wing, have been sponsoring the DARPA Grand Challenge.
And it is an attempt to sort of foster these automated autonomous driving technologies.
And the advantage there is if a car drives itself, it talks to other cars, traffic can be expedited, accidents can be avoided.
If accidents can be avoided, these cars themselves can be made lighter because they don't have to be big steel boxes to sustain crash energies, and so they save fuel.
Many cascading advantages to this technology.
And it's coming.
You know, like for example, the Infiniti EX35 has lane departure correction.
Right.
So if you happen to wander out of lane, the car will correct and pull you back in a lane.
Wow.
You may or may not like that.
You can turn it off, thank God.
Well, the self-driving thing kind of appeals to me as midlife.
You know, I like the idea of not having to - I can't afford a chauffer but I don't have to drive.
(Soundbite of laughter)
However, I think, I'll be well past midlife before those cars are on the highway, I would think.
Well, maybe not.
I don't know how old you are.
But imagine this, you get in your car, you punch the button and then you read the paper while the car drives you to work.
Incredible.
(Soundbite of laughter)
What about speed?

What about, you know, that's what I think that - I mean, that's my sort of idea of what somebody would want to get them out of some kind of midlife slump - that they would want a really slick speedy car.
Hmm, yeah.
There are some slick speedy cars out there.
The frontiers of horsepower and top speed are being pushed back all the time.
I mentioned the Corvette ZR1 - 620 horsepower, a 595 foot-pound of torque, over 200 miles per hour.
There is the Cadillac CTS-V.
Now, this is a regular Cadillac, right?
But it's got 550 horsepower.
And then there is the Audi R8 V12 TDI.
This is a diesel car.
So if you want to be a little bit greener with your supercar, you can, you know, claim that.
And it also is a 200-mile-per-hour car.
So there's a lot of big, fast cars out there if you want to go that fast.
Tell me a little bit more about the green cars that are out there.
Well, if you didn't have a battery story or an electric story or a hybrid story at the Detroit auto show this week, you didn't have any story to tell.
You know, both Ford and Dodge came out with their new pickup trucks.
Well, the Ford F-150 pickup truck, is the best-selling vehicle in America, has been donkey's years.
And nobody cared, right?
Because it's just another pickup, you know, and it's just one more nail in that particular coffin.
But for example, Honda displayed something that would be kind of called a Prius pickup.
It's a, you know, it's the Prius but it's also in a pickup format.
A company named Fisker, started by Henrik Fisker - he's a famous designer - showed an $80,000 sports car - long, sleek, erotic shape - that was a plug-in battery hybrid.
And so when, for example, four years ago, nobody was talking about electric cars.
Nobody was talking about batteries or - the only car out there that was credible in this was a Prius.
Now, everybody has got to have one.
